Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Supporting Patterns for Embedded Network Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Embedded network systems are transforming the planetary compute fabric, changing the way we coordinate with peers, safeguard natural resources, and protect local communities. Ensuring the correctness and performance of these systems has immediate relevance to the health and welfare of the planet. The objective of this CAREER project is to develop the theoretical and applied foundations necessary to ensure these properties and to instill the requisite skills in the next generation of embedded network system engineers. The project relies on a pattern-centric approach motivated by the profound impact of design patterns on software reliability and programmer productivity in other domains and the observation that these benefits can be amplified through the development of formal foundations and supporting software tools.

There are four project components: First, the team is codifying expert knowledge in the form of new patterns for embedded network system design and implementation. Second, the team is developing a specification and reasoning formalism to capture pattern requirements precisely and to validate the correctness of pattern implementations. Third, the team is developing static analysis techniques and supporting software tools to automate the detection of pattern implementation errors. Finally, the team is applying these techniques and tools to reverse-engineering and code generation tasks, extending the benefits of model-based software engineering to this new domain. The dissemination and outreach program includes publication, undergraduate and graduate curriculum integration, undergraduate research involvement, high-school outreach and engagement, academic and dissemination to industry, and mini-workshops for evaluation and promulgation of findings, methods and tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project began in 2008, with the prediction that embedded network systems would be the principal enablers of the ubiquitous computing vision. Today, that prediction has become a reality. Embedded network systems, and sensor network systems in particular, have transformed the computing landscape and made their way into our homes and cars, fields and forests, buildings and roads, and a host of other places. This new paradigm of a deeply connected, silently chattering world is today referred to as the Internet of Things -- where everyday objects sense, compute, and communicate to provide real-time visibility into conditions, trends, and patterns at dense temporal and spatial scales. The resulting situational awareness promises profound impact across disparate domains. These systems are changing the way we interact and coordinate with our peers, study the ecology of our planet, manage our water resources, monitor our civil infrastructure, manage and respond to emergencies, and protect our communities. Deploying embedded network systems that behave as expected in a manner that is time and cost-effective has immediate relevance to the health and welfare of the nation and its citizens. Enabling the predictable design, implementation, and maintenance of these systems has been the focus of this CAREER project. 


The project has contributed to the theoretical and applied foundations necessary to design, implement, and maintain embedded network systems. The technical work spanned an array of topics in computing. It resulted in new mathematical formalisms for reasoning about embedded network systems; new design guidelines for ensuring their robust construction; new algorithms for use in specific applications; new software tools for implementation and evaluation; and a number of other related contributions. The project has resulted in more than 50 publications and multiple patent applications. At the same time, it has had a significant impact in training future generations of computing researchers and practitioners. The project has directly supported 6 PhD students (3 women), 3 MS students (1 woman), and 7 BS students. It has also supported outreach programs reaching hundreds of middle and high school students, with approximately 50% from underrepresented groups in computing. Awards resulting from the project include two best paper awards and multiple student research awards.
